the Mississauga Hospital,

828.80.text:

835.97.text:

837.87.text:

what's going to happen

841.04.text:

843.14.text:

845.95.text:
to be a little bit

847.91.text:

849.68.text:
because I was so tired

really helped make

861.69.text:

866.97.text:

868.57.text:

875.81.text:

882.68.text:
You need to be mentally prepared

Breastfeeding is the one thing

914.01.text:
That's a big thing,

917.28.text:

920.15.text: That would be my line, I think.

933.23.text:
(female narrator)
If your doctor
or midwife has told you

934.60.text:
that you are likely to have
a caesarean birth,

936.20.text:
here are some suggestions
to help you

937.97.text:
and your baby get off
to a good start.

942.81.text:
Most mothers are awake during
their baby's caesarean birth.

946.58.text:
The relaxation exercises you
learned in your prenatal classes

950.62.text:
will help you now
and during your recovery.

957.09.text:
It's very important for babies
to be held or placed

959.96.text:
skin to skin as soon as
possible after the birth.

963.83.text:
Your physician and nurse
will help you with this.

967.17.text:
Skin-to-skin contact helps
babies adjust to life

969.87.text:
outside the womb
by keeping them warm

976.34.text:
It also soothes
and comforts babies,

986.35.text:
The nurse may also
encourage your partner

988.45.text: to hold the baby skin to skin.

990.49.text:
It's an amazing experience
to share with your newborn.

1000.40.text:
(female narrator)
Babies like to feed at night
because the hormone

1003.00.text:
that helps your body make
more milk is higher at night.

1006.14.text:
(female)
Sometimes my baby would have
a stretch of feeding non-stop,

1009.34.text:

1012.45.text:
The nurse told me

1016.52.text: At first I thought it was a sign

1018.42.text:
that I didn't have enough milk

1021.02.text:
but in fact, this is the way
my baby was telling my body

Your partner

To prepare for these

it's better for your

No, but rather think,

and continued to help me
every two hours

1390.42.text:
the whole time I was
at the hospital.

1391.96.text:
So, it's a--since then it's been
a great experience

1395.33.text:
and probably the best choice
that I've made for me

1399.00.text:
(Patti Cochrane)
And so when you
went home, were you--

1401.13.text:
did you have any issues
or problems then?

1405.24.text:
But one of the things that was
done for me at the hospital

1407.84.text:
was a breastfeeding class
before we left.

1411.51.text:
So, for me and my husband
to go with all the other couples

1414.55.text:
and see if we were
having any trouble.

1417.52.text:
We had a lactation consultant
come right to our room

1419.92.text:
before discharge, and then we
were set up with an appointment

1422.19.text:
at a breastfeeding clinic
close by our home

1425.59.text:
for a couple of days
postpartum.

1427.56.text:
I went there and I took my
mother-in-law with me

1430.40.text:
and got the support there
that I was doing a great job,

1433.90.text:
and so for me it was
a seamless transition

1440.97.text:
(Patti Cochrane)
And if you choose
to have another child,

1445.48.text:
(Patti Cochrane)
And any advice
to viewers

1450.48.text:
then pre-natal education
is the most important thing

1456.69.text:
with you and your partner
or your spouse.

1459.99.text:
If you have a baby
and you want to breastfeed,

1463.13.text:
then to seek out the resources
in the community

1465.43.text:
that are there for you
that can help you,

1470.27.text:
And take control over those
moments after birth

1474.67.text:
and how you want
to feed your baby

1476.31.text:
and make sure that people
are around you

1477.91.text:
that support your
choices as well.

1481.41.text:
I think that that's the most
important thing,

1483.68.text:
and ultimately to encourage
new moms that you do have

1488.35.text:
the ability to completely
nourish your infant

1491.22.text:
for the first 6 months
in life and beyond.

1495.29.text:
Were there any other partners
in the community,

1497.23.text: 'cause we have moms in the home,

1498.83.text:
but what happens when
they go to the community?

1500.93.text:
Who were our partners?
Just a little couple seconds.

1504.90.text:
and we couldn't do it
without them--

1506.54.text:
is our partners
at Peel Public Health.

1508.11.text:
They are instrumental
in that continuum of care

1512.14.text:
So, we have a little small piece
at Trillium Health Partners,

1514.68.text: and that journey is really long

1516.42.text:
and they work prenatally,
they work postnatally,

1518.85.text:
and we couldn't do it
without them,

1520.22.text:
and we've built our partnership
and it's nice and strong now

1522.42.text:
and it's just going
to get stronger.

1525.39.text:
Thank you for
joining me today,

1528.79.text:
We will be coming back to learn
more around foot complications.

1568.67.text:
(Patti Cochrane)
Welcome back
to Talk Trillium.

1570.60.text:
This segment we're going
to talk about

1574.17.text:
And joining us today
we have three guests.

1576.51.text:
Heather Nutbeem,
Heather is a patient

1579.31.text:
who's had some
experience in this.

1581.21.text:
Rob Renton is
a clinical educator

1585.02.text:
but he's also our
organizational-wide project lead

1589.22.text:
And Fiona Ryan,
who's an RN,

1591.49.text:
who delivers wound care
for this patient population.

1595.53.text:
So maybe my first question
to you, Rob:

1597.93.text:
why is diabetic foot wounds
and complications

1601.10.text:
such an important initiative
for Trillium Health Partners?

1604.80.text:
(Rob Renton)
Well, within our
own community,

1607.37.text:
there's the diabetes management
centre that I work with,

1615.45.text:
And of that 70,000 patients,
about 2% will go on to develop

1628.76.text:
a wound on the foot has
a higher mortality rate than--

1634.40.text:
than breast cancer
or prostate cancer,

1636.47.text:
so it's a very significant
indicator of overall health

1643.98.text:
(Patti Cochrane)
And what is it
about diabetes and wounds

1650.62.text:
Any diabetics fail
to heal as rapidly?

1655.42.text:
(Rob Renton)
Absolutely,
that's a big part of it.

1657.19.text:
Yeah, their ability
to sense the wound

1658.86.text: in the bottom of their foot.

1664.43.text:
Obviously, a wound in the foot
is sort of an indicator, then,

1671.27.text:
Obviously, other parts
of that body, then,

1673.44.text:
are being affected
by the impaired circulation

1678.91.text:
So it goes on to become problems
for heart and kidney and so on,

1682.98.text:
and that just becomes a spiral
of unfortunate ill-health

1691.39.text:
and most specifically the wound,
healing in the foot,

1693.79.text:
can becomes gangrenous
and lead to amputations

1698.50.text:
(Patti Cochrane)
Yeah, so it's
a very serious thing

1700.27.text:
that need a lot
of attention.

1702.07.text:
So this is a very
important initiative for us.

1704.84.text: Fiona, can you describe for us?

1708.44.text:
and you deliver
wound care in your role.

1710.04.text:
What does the reducing
foot complications BPSO,

1713.55.text:
or Best Practice Spotlight
Organization guideline,

1716.52.text:
tell us to do differently
than what you did before?

1719.65.text:
(Fiona Ryan)
The difference between
what we've been doing before

1721.55.text:
and what we've been
doing with this new guideline

1724.02.text:
is as soon as a patient is
coming into the hospital,

1729.06.text:
So, we're assessing
the patient's sensation,

1733.93.text:
which is a little piece
of plastic

1735.77.text:
which will gently touch
the bottom of the patient's foot

1738.17.text:
to see whether or not
they can feel it.

1740.37.text:
We will be looking for just
the appearance of the foot,

1743.41.text:
whether or not it has healthy
skin or healthy toes,

1749.25.text:
how they're taking care
of their feet at home,

1751.22.text: if they know what they're doing,

1752.78.text:
and if there's any gaps
in their knowledge

1756.19.text:
(Patti Cochrane)
So, prevention is a big key,
and it sounds like that's

1758.59.text:
what some of this initiative
is trying to do is really

1761.86.text:
look at diabetic foots
before a problem starts.

1767.60.text:
We have an opportunity
to catch these diabetic

1772.60.text:
If somebody's walking
through the doors

1774.64.text:
and they have decreased
sensation in their feet,

1777.08.text:
we can move them forward
with education and knowledge

1780.48.text:
in order to avoid
any more complications.

1784.08.text:
(Patti Cochrane)
So, Heather, thank you
for joining us today.

1787.29.text:
You're a patient,
and I understand

1793.19.text:
(Patti Cochrane)
And you had a wound
complication, have you?

1800.53.text:
I got involved with the diabetic
foot management people

1803.17.text:
after my doctor had
a little bit of a shock

1805.54.text:
when I told him I got cut
after having a pedicure,

1810.44.text:
No more pedicures for you.
This is where you go."

1812.48.text:
So, I thought, "Well,
I'll take his advice."

1814.65.text:
And off I went and I been
going there ever since

1816.28.text:
and they've even helped me
take care of my feet.

1818.18.text:
So, listening to these folks
talk about prevention,

1820.15.text:
that's what I'm trying to do
is to look after things

1825.76.text:
And any other advice
that you might have to give

1827.79.text:
for other listeners
who might have diabetes?

1832.10.text:
(Heather Nutbeem)
In anything I've heard
it seems that don't wait.

1835.23.text: Get on with things right away.

1836.97.text:
Don't say, "Okay,
I'll look after that later.

1838.60.text:
I'll make a new year's
resolution to take care of it."

1840.47.text:
You got to do it right now,
'cause that's how you look

1845.11.text:
(Patti Cochrane)
And I understand
a statistic that if diabetics

1847.11.text:
had annual foot exams,
it would actually reduce

1849.55.text:
the rate of amputations within
this country significantly.

1853.62.text:
So, really, prevention
is the key for good care.

1858.26.text:
Now, Rob, you just showed me
a little bit of a package

1861.89.text:
that you provide
for diabetic patients

1865.76.text:
Talk to me a little bit about
what's in that package.

1868.00.text:
And I notice an interesting
pamphlet there

1872.50.text:
(Rob Renton)
Right, well, there's
the monofilament,

1874.44.text:
just to show that, that Fiona
had mentioned a second ago

1878.98.text:
So, I look at this package as
a one-stop shopping place

1883.22.text:
for the nurses and the units
to get the information

1887.09.text:
The pamphlet, the information
that's given to the patient,

1890.19.text:
includes a little bit
about some creams,

1892.79.text:
some community resources,
and then this,

1894.93.text:
as you mentioned,
the dos and don'ts.

1896.73.text:
Some of the simple dos
and don'ts would be things

1899.03.text:
like make sure that you have
an assessment done

1904.64.text:
When you're with them, ensure
you're taking off your shoes

1906.87.text:
and having them
assess your feet.

1909.64.text:
The neuropathies that we assess
for using the monofilament test

1914.05.text:
are a big indicator
of the worry or potential

1918.88.text:
so another dos and don'ts
would be make sure that

1921.02.text:
you check your shoes carefully
before you put them on.

1923.59.text:
That something
hasn't fallen into them.

1925.46.text:
Make sure you wear
shoes all the time,

1926.86.text:
slippers at home, always
shoes when you go outside.

1929.03.text:
Never take a chance walking
around without shoes on

1931.83.text:
so you know that you're
protecting your feet,

1935.73.text:
and neuropathies
won't be able to tell

1937.57.text:
if they've cut
or injured their feet,

1939.30.text:
and it becomes much more
of a problem for them.

1941.44.text:
Some of the other dos
and don'ts are be cautious,

1943.24.text:
be extremely cautious when
going to have a pedicure done.

1946.78.text:
When you're cutting
your own toenails,

1948.35.text:
make sure that
they're cut straight

1951.42.text:
If you do notice a cut,
treat it very seriously,

1954.29.text:
even to the point where you may
want to seek professional help

1957.36.text:
if you should cut your feet
or damage your feet in any way.

1961.23.text:
Other creams, ointments,
how to manage

1964.00.text:
who to get support from,
who to--

1968.50.text:
to help be involved with this,
that they know the risks

1971.34.text:
and are available
to help you out

1972.80.text:
should you at some point
need their assistance

1975.01.text: to manage some of these things.

1976.61.text:
'Cause not everyone's
able to easily check

1979.41.text:
and that's something
that should be done daily

1981.18.text:
is checking the bottom
of your feet.

1982.65.text:
So, if you may need
your help with your partner

1984.78.text:
to help manage that type
of care or inspection.

1990.39.text:
Now, Fiona, education's
a really critical component,

1992.72.text: as we just heard from Rob.

1994.83.text:
So, how do you build education
into the work that you do?

1998.20.text: Or is that the bulk of the work?

2000.03.text:
(Fiona Ryan)
A lot of the time
it's a discussion.

2002.53.text:
When we get
the diabetic inpatient,

2005.50.text:
they're usually there
for another reason.

2007.34.text:
They're not in the hospital
to have their feet checked,

2009.34.text:
so a lot of the time it
comes kind of at a surprise

2011.94.text:
when I walk into
the patient's room

2013.58.text:
and they're getting ready
for a surgery, and I'm,

2015.48.text:
"Do you mind if I
take a look at your feet?"

2017.65.text:
And I'm asking them
about education on their feet.

2022.39.text:
Usually that's an opportunity
to catch them at a surprise,

2025.62.text:
and we'll really find out
what they know

2030.83.text:
That's when we can find
the gaps in their knowledge.

2035.37.text:
(Patti Cochrane)
So, Heather, you mentioned
that you go now

2037.87.text:
to a diabetic centre
to get your feet assessed.

2041.71.text:
What do they actually do
in there in that centre?

2048.45.text:
They give my feet
a really good inspection,

2050.68.text:
they cut the toenails,
they file all the callouses off,

2053.52.text:
and give me the good
old lecture of making sure

2056.39.text:
I keep them well and truly
moisturized every night,

2058.79.text: and I hate the feeling of cream,

2060.36.text:
but knowing I'm going to get
that lecture, I do it.

2064.26.text:
(Patti Cochrane)
So there's benefit,
other tips about managing

2068.50.text:
Because diabetes is much more
than just a foot inspection.

2075.14.text:
You can never take
a holiday from it.

2076.71.text:
You can't get away from it,
but if you just sort of always

2079.34.text:
have it in the back
of your mind,

2080.81.text:
you can just keep going
and not worry about it too much.

2082.65.text:
(Patti Cochrane)
And I understand eye exams

2085.55.text:
(Heather Nutbeem)
Yeah, and I have it
every year,

2087.19.text:
and my doctor's
very careful about making sure

2089.22.text:
he asks me that question
every time I go to see him.

2093.43.text:
So, eye exams are
important annually,

2097.30.text:
anything else in managing
diabetes that you would say?

2100.77.text:
(Heather Nutbeem)
Just keep track
of everything,

2102.80.text:
because something can
change very quickly,

2105.30.text:
and so know what's happening
with your own blood sugars

2108.77.text:
and what's going on
and stay active.

2112.71.text:
(Patti Cochrane)
And so, Rob, can you
tell us a little bit more?

2115.68.text:
Are you tracking
your outcomes and?

2118.15.text:
(Rob Renton)
Yeah, and that's been really
a relatively easy thing to do.

2121.59.text:
I was very fortunate
to work with

2124.56.text:
and they were able
to write a very--

2126.19.text:
a neat little program that
checks in the background,

2128.33.text:
looks at the medication
the patients are admitted with,

2130.70.text:
and anyone that was
on any type of insulin

2132.86.text:
or hypoglycemic medicine
is then determined

2135.70.text:
to be diabetic or have diabetes,
I should say.

2139.24.text:
From there it's just
three other things,

2141.44.text:
three other simple things:
have they had the education,

2144.38.text:
have they had
the monofilament test,

2146.41.text:
and have they had
the assessment done?

2149.68.text:
We're doing really well
in the units,

2151.18.text:
around usually at least 70%
to 80% compliance rate.

2154.12.text:
It's a relatively short
simple assessment,

2157.49.text:
a little bit of education,
and then it becomes part

2160.16.text:
of the permanent record
so we can see later on

2164.50.text:
(Patti Cochrane)
And is that right
across the organization?

2166.23.text:
(Rob Renton)
We're getting there,
we're on six units so far

2168.17.text:
and about three or four units
at Credit Valley,

2173.04.text:
but we still got
some work to do.

2177.54.text:
And Rob or Fiona, what about
partnerships with the community?

2180.45.text:
So, we discharge patients
from our hospital.

2182.51.text:
Is there any kind of link
with our community partners

2187.69.text:
(Rob Renton)
There's a couple of links
that we've established.

2189.75.text:
The people from Coloplast
have given me

2193.96.text:
a great deal of education,
education materials,

2197.50.text:
samples for the cream that you
were talking about a minute ago,

2200.40.text:
to make sure that people's
feet are moisturized,

2208.31.text:
It requires a referral
from the family physician,

2211.71.text:
so we try to connect with
the family physicians

2213.91.text:
to make sure they know
what's available and what's--

2217.42.text:
and how to connect with
diabetes management centres.

2219.85.text:
So, there's a few community
resources like that,

2222.35.text:
that have been helpful,
really helpful

2229.23.text:
(Patti Cochrane)
And, Fiona, any advice
that you want to give,

2231.30.text:
either to patients or to other
healthcare providers?

2234.93.text:
(Fiona Ryan)
I would just, kind of what
Heather was saying.

2236.94.text:
Just to motivate the person
or the patient

2238.87.text: to check their feet every day.

2240.74.text:
It's really important
to take a look at your toes

2242.51.text: and the bottom of your feet

2243.88.text:
to see if there's any changes
going on.

2246.21.text:
Oftentimes we have
the elderly person

2247.98.text:
who doesn't have
the ability to lift their foot,

2250.85.text:
and unfortunately, they might
not have somebody at home

2253.42.text: who can look at them as well.

2255.05.text:
So, I often suggest
to just get a little mirror.

2257.42.text:
A little mirror,
to sit on the couch,

2258.99.text:
and they can look
at the bottom of their feet--

2261.96.text:
(Fiona Ryan)
Just think of different ways
to get people to look

2264.86.text: at their feet every single day,

2266.56.text:
because a teeny little scratch
can grow into a mountain,

2269.97.text:
and we can have much bigger
problems on our hands.

2272.77.text:
(Patti Cochrane)
Okay, well, I want
to thank the three of you

2276.84.text:
I certainly learned
a lot more

2282.98.text:
And I want our viewers to stay
tuned for after the break,

2285.98.text:
because we're going to learn
more around smoking cessation,

2289.12.text:
and I'm sure
that smoking cessation

2292.99.text:
that you hear about
as you learn more

2298.20.text:
So, I think smoking cessation
applies for a large part

2301.80.text:
of our population,
so stay tuned after the break.

2351.52.text:
to Talk Trillium:
Partnering for Patients.

2354.22.text:
Today, joining me
is Priti Patel.

2356.75.text:
Priti is the manager of smoking
cessation, primary care,

2359.52.text:
and seniors' health
at Trillium Health Partners.

2361.93.text:
And we have Robin Pohl, who's
a cardiovascular rehab tech

2365.60.text:
and also the smoking
cessation champion.

2368.67.text:
Now, we all know that smoking
and quitting smoking

2371.54.text:
is good for us, both in
the short term and long term,

2375.21.text:
has long-lasting effects
for our health.

2378.61.text:
And with a lot of determination
and education,

2382.61.text:
many patients can be
successful in their journey

2385.35.text:
to improve their health
by quitting smoking.

2388.29.text:
And so it's really our delight
to have both of you joining

2391.32.text:
here today to share with us
how Trillium Health Partners

2394.06.text:
is helping patients quit smoking
at a very opportunistic time,

2398.70.text:
I would say, and that's
when they encounter

2403.64.text:
and it sometimes gives them
a little bit of a jolt

2405.97.text:
and inspires them
to quit smoking.

2408.37.text:
So, as the smoking cessation
champion, Robin,

2411.38.text: tell me a little bit about

2413.28.text:
what that smoking cessation
journey looks like.

2417.15.text:
(Robin Pohl)
I work in
the Cardiovascular Care Program.

2420.12.text:
When a patient
comes into the hospital

2424.06.text:
so a heart attack
or needing surgery--

2426.79.text:
we actually first
meet them at bedside

2430.33.text:
and ask them
if they need help

2433.60.text:
or if they would like
to stop smoking.

2437.30.text:
We advise them on the fact
that it's one of the best things

2442.37.text:
they can do for their health,
to stop smoking.

2446.28.text: When they come to our program,

2448.31.text:
it's an education
and exercise program

2452.15.text:
for their heart health,
and we assess

2455.75.text:
if they are in need of help
in stopping smoking.

2460.59.text:
(Patti Cochrane)
The thing about
smoking cessation is

2464.36.text:
Whether you're 40 years old
or 80 years old,

2466.97.text:
there are always benefits
from quitting smoking,

2471.97.text:
(Robin Pohl)
Yes, even in just 48 hours,
you can improve your health

2479.41.text:
You reduce the amount
of carbon dioxide in the blood,

2484.18.text:
more oxygen in the blood
to feed the cells,

2487.89.text:
less damage to the cells,
it's that quick a change.

2492.69.text:
(Patti Cochrane)
So, in 48 hours there can be
very positive effects

2500.00.text:
(Patti Cochrane)
So, how long
does it take to become--

2502.20.text:
for your lungs to return
to normal state

2509.74.text:
(Robin Pohl)
The difficult thing
with your lungs

2511.58.text:
is once the alveoli are damaged,
they don't recover;

2517.65.text:
however, you can reduce
your risk of another heart event

2524.49.text:
Within 15 years you have
the same risk of a heart event

2532.03.text:
(Patti Cochrane)
And, Priti, you are
the manager

2534.63.text:
overseeing smoking cessation
across the organization.

2538.30.text:
Tell me a little bit
about that program,

2540.17.text: and what does that look like?

2542.31.text:
(Priti Patel)
So, as Robin has highlighted,
the key part of the program

2547.98.text:
is really making sure that we
ask all of our patients

2552.45.text:
their smoking status and asses
their readiness to quit.

2556.12.text:
So, some individuals, you know,
you walk into their room

2560.66.text:
Other individuals,
it may take a few tries,

2562.79.text:
and as Robin highlighted,
it's advising them

2567.43.text:
And then the key piece for us
is really offering them

2578.64.text:
and then ensuring that there
is follow-up for them.

2581.95.text:
So, our program is
quite comprehensive.

2586.08.text:
And the other elements
to our program is also helping

2590.89.text:
to build capacity within
our organization,

2594.63.text: so making it easy for our staff

2598.90.text:
to have that conversation
with patients

2602.13.text:
and their families about
the importance of quitting.

2605.77.text:
(Patti Cochrane)
Now, when a patient
gets admitted to hospital,

2608.27.text:
I know we don't allow
smoking on the premises,

2612.58.text: so what do we do for patients

2614.41.text:
that were heavy smokers
before they came into hospital

2618.58.text:
Is there something we can do
to prevent them

2620.82.text:
from actually experiencing
wanting a cigarette?

2625.46.text:
(Priti Patel)
Yes, absolutely, and that's
why it's really important

2633.30.text:
and usually within 24
to 48 hours of admission.

2636.93.text:
And there are lots
of different types

2646.24.text:
there's lots of things
that we can help--

2650.15.text:
to help our patents with
the withdrawal symptoms

2654.39.text:
(Patti Cochrane)
And, Robin, is there
a prescription or something

2657.62.text:
that you always order in order
to help patients quit smoking?

2664.66.text:
(Robin Pohl)
When I am advising patients
and assisting the ones

2668.63.text:
that have decided
they would like to quit,

2674.71.text:
I offer them advice on different
types of medications

2679.48.text:
For instance,
you said a prescription.

2686.52.text:
but I can advise them on things
that are over the counter,

2692.09.text:
And the general rule is
one milligram to one cigarette,

2696.96.text:
so if a person normally would
smoke seven cigarettes per day,

2702.80.text:
"Try to start with
a 7-milligram nicotine patch."

2707.77.text:
We can advise them on other
options that they can talk

2710.94.text:
to their physician with--
about, sorry--

2717.45.text:
It's a type of medication that
really helps people not feel

2723.89.text: the urge to smoke as much.

2726.42.text:
Or another medication called
Zyban, but again that's--

2733.00.text:
a physician would prescribe
a medication like that.

2736.77.text:
All the medications work best
when people get support,

2741.51.text:
support from family,
support from friends,

2745.34.text:
support from medical educators,
and of course,

2756.35.text:
(Patti Cochrane)
And so the support,
when people are discharged

2759.86.text:
what kind of support can they
expect from our community?

2764.93.text:
(Robin Pohl)
There is a lot of support,
and you just have to ask.

2771.47.text:
You can go
to your own pharmacist,

2774.67.text:
and your pharmacist
can give you support

2782.55.text:
The Peel Health Program, you can
contact them and get support.

2788.99.text:
The Canadian Cancer Society
has an amazing website,

2796.89.text:
You don't have to call,
you can email,

2798.83.text:
you can text,
you can pick up resources.

2804.77.text:
(Patti Cochrane)
Is there a phone number
that you want to share

2807.97.text:
(Robin Pohl)
Sure, I'll show you
some of the pamphlets

2813.98.text:
and on the back is
the full number

2817.62.text:
This is the little card
that we do give our patients.

2826.72.text:
sorry I don't see
very well-- 513-5333.

2833.70.text:
So those are additional
resources for people

2844.04.text:
It's called TelASK,
and so if patients consent,

2848.45.text:
three days after they're
discharged from the hospital

2853.68.text:
they can receive
an automated telephone call,

2856.39.text:
and the system will call them
up to eight times

2860.19.text:
and follow them
for about six months,

2862.26.text:
and at any time during
that telephone call,

2866.46.text:
if you want to talk
to somebody live,

2870.17.text:
then you can press to get
the smokers' helpline

2872.74.text:
and then you would be
able to connect

2874.57.text:
with a live person who can
then help support you as well.

2877.14.text:
So that's another piece that
we have to support our patients

2882.48.text:
after they've been discharged
from the hospital.

2885.08.text:
(Patti Cochrane)
It seems like maybe
a breakthrough strategy

2888.42.text:
because sometimes it's
just that sudden urge,

2890.65.text:
and if they could just get
through the next few minutes,

2893.02.text:
they can somehow sustain
their desire to quit smoking.

2897.63.text:
And I think Nicorette gums
are sometimes a fast relief,

2900.73.text:
is that still a recommended
strategy, Robin?

2904.00.text:
(Robin Pohl)
That's one strategy.
What we say is try the four Ds.

2911.98.text:
So delay the thought of smoking
for a few minutes.

2915.65.text:
D for drink,
have a drink of water.

2920.12.text:
Distract yourself, you know,
call a friend, call a friend.

2927.86.text:
(Robin Pohl)
And for some reason,
delay, distract, drink, I--

2932.63.text:
for some reason I've
forgotten the fourth D.

2935.60.text:
(Patti Cochrane)
I think that could apply
for almost anything.

2938.20.text:
If we were on a diet and we
wanted to delay eating

2940.14.text:
another piece of food,
that would help as well.

2943.14.text:
(Priti Patel)
I think the key is
that you want to know

2947.95.text:
what are your triggers
for smoking,

2949.61.text:
and making sure that you have
other options available.

2952.75.text:
So, if you are the type of
individual who has breakfast

2956.45.text:
and then you always have
a cigarette afterwards,

2958.56.text: well, now that you're going to--

2960.66.text:
Part of your plan is, okay,
after breakfast,

2962.59.text: what am I going to do?

2966.10.text:
Maybe I'm going to go
for a quick walk

2967.73.text:
so I'm not thinking about
having that cigarette,

2969.83.text:
so you really have
to sort of plan

2973.14.text:
and make sure
that you understand

2977.34.text:
(Patti Cochrane)
That's got an added benefit,
of course, of adding activity.

2980.24.text:
Because often weight gain is
a concern once we quit smoking,

2984.15.text:
so that's a good replacement
for smoking.

2986.62.text:
And what are the impacts
of smokers

2990.29.text:
Are there any statistics
on that?

2994.73.text:
You know, so for example,
on any given day across Canada

2999.26.text:
there are about 23,000 beds
that are occupied by smokers,

3003.80.text:
and there's also
huge financial cost.

3007.34.text:
So, it costs the healthcare
system 1.6 billion dollars,

3013.24.text:
but it's not just the cost
to the healthcare system,

3015.91.text:
there's also the cost
of lost productivity,

3023.89.text:
So, smoking-related cost,
that's about 6 billion dollars,

3028.06.text:
so think about all
of the wonderful

3030.09.text:
programs and services
that 6 billion dollars

3036.83.text:
And I guess the other
piece to remember

3040.14.text:
is not just the cost,
but also smokers

3043.94.text:
tend to live 10 years less
than non-smokers,

3047.54.text: so it's important for a life

3051.52.text:
and a quality of life
perspective as well.

3053.72.text:
(Patti Cochrane)
Wow, I wasn't aware
of that statistic.

3055.55.text:
So smokers actually live
10 years less

3061.49.text:
And if that isn't a rationale
for quitting smoking,

3064.43.text: I'm not sure what would be.

3066.26.text:
So, thank you so much
for sharing

3068.03.text:
all of your insights
into smoking cessation today

3070.80.text:
and how our best practices
actually help our patients

3074.41.text:
in the long term as well
as the short term.

3079.14.text:
if you need
any further information

3081.61.text:
about anything that we've
talked about today,

3084.48.text:
please visit our website at
www.trilliumhealthpartners.ca.

3089.72.text:
It was great to learn more
about how the organization

3092.46.text:
is lifting best practices
right across all three sites

3097.93.text:
and we look forward
to hearing more.
